content: One way is to export your mail folder contents to individual email messages in .eml format. Then download the email viewer at https://www.systoolsgroup.com/eml-viewer.html - free. The addon importexporttools can export messages to eml by highlighting the folder, rightclicking and selecting the importexport option to export as eml files . The product I show is an example; I'm sure there are other eml viewers out there. Another option is to read the mail folder directly with an mbox viewer, one of which is https://www.nucleustechnologies.com/mbox-viewer-free.html
creator: davidsk

content: Unfortunately, no.
creator: davidsk

content: It appears at first guess that something is preventing prefs.js from updating when Thunderbird is closed. Possibly an anti-virus? Or maybe the prefs.js file is set to read-only. I would check via windows file explorer to see status there. click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profile folder', click 'open folder', exit thunderbird, and see if there are multiple copies of prefs.js. if so, I suggest deleting all but the newest, and rename that one to prefs.js, and restart and see if that helps.
creator: davidsk

content: Hi David. Thanks for your reply. Since posting my question, I found that I can designate the Local Folders Inbox to store my online account's emails in Account Settings> Server Settings> Advanced Settings >"When downloading mail from this account's server, use the following folder to store new messages". Viz: https://mzl.la/3paHirGe. Regards, Roger
creator: rogersquier

content: The profile is at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles. The name of the profile is at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles.ini that is a simple text file and will have name of the profile folder that is in the above mentioned '...thunderbird\profiles' folder. Do a screenshot of the 'Mail' folder and the 'Mail\Local Folders' folder.
creator: davidsk

content:
Try this: - start thunderbird. if pane to create email account appears, close it - click alt key to show menu bar if not visible - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down left side to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles' -click 'create profile' - click next - enter short nickname for folder, such as MYPROFILE - click choose' button - locate and select your profile and click finish - on next pane, locate your profile and click the 'launch' button

This process lets Thunderbird update the ini files for you.
creator: davidsk
